I believe this is a textbook example where TestNG would=

As I said earlier, TestNG groups allow you to corelate test methods =
together
in a looser way than with packages and classes.  Test methods can =
also
belong to several groups at the same time:

@Test(groups =3D { "functi=
onal", "database", "table.account" })
public void insertIntoAccount() { ...=
 }

This annotation flags this test as 

- Part of the functional (or accep=
tance) suite, which means it will be part
of the nightly tests that exercis=
e your entire application

- It's also part of the database group, which me=
ans it does something with
the database.  If you make a modification to you=
r front-end code, you
probably don't need to run it

- More specifically, i=
t states that it modifies the table ACCOUNT.  This
way, if you make a modif=
ication to this table's schema, you can run only
these tests that touch thi=
s table.

And as I mentioned above, groups are also used to calculate depen=
dencies and
guarantee that groups of methods ("launch-server") are always r=
un and
succeed before a next group of tests is run ("servlet").
